page.title: 02Local History-Melchbourne
page.content: Melchbourne was an important village in Medieaval times, being bound up with the Knights Hospitallers of the order of St. John. A fair was held on the feast of St. Mary Magdalen after licence was granted in 1264 and Feast Sunday is still observed in the church on the second Sunday in July. A market was held every Friday. During the Reformation the Order was supressed and the lands were granted to the Earl of Bedford. Lord St. John of Bletsoe acquired Melchbourne in 17th century and transferred his seat from Bletsoe Castle. The Estate remained with successive Lords St. John until the Second World War. Until the Estate was sold off everyone who lived in Melchbourne worked the estate and went to Church on Sundays.
